Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2015 06:26AM kris1114 wrote: Waiting really is brutal. I was diagnosed on Dec.3rd 2014 and went through a battery of tests, and felt like each time I was shoved back into that perpetual waiting room. Now, I had my mastectomy on the 30th and waiting once again on the final pathology report. I can say though, after surgery, I did not feel depressed by how I looked and although a smidge bummed, I still feel confident. I saw it as a hurdle and an acheivement. Each hurdle you leap over, the more confident you feel. Keep your sense of humor up, it is SO important and lean on your support system. Your family and friends are itching to help you. I try not to lean too much, because independence is important too, but allow yourself to "trust fall" into your supportive wall of love when you need it, every time. Body surf over your support and feel the waves of comfort wash over you.
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed Leighrh greenae

Posts.Content: kris1114 wrote: I had a bilateral simple mastectomy on Dec. 31st. My surgeon said margins were ok were his words. The oncologist never breathed a word. Well, I had several issues with the original Oncologist that made me uncomfortable long story short. I went to my primary doctor for a referral to a new Oncologist and one that was closer. The new doctor pointed out the positive margin right away and asked me about it. I was stunned. I didn't have a clue. She got on the phone w/ the pathologist and confirmed it was in fact positive and I had bloodwork for chemo and left with office with the plan to see the breast surgeon she uses for a 2nd opinion. I am still going to that this upcoming Wednesday the 25th. Well, I get a call back, and Doc says she spoke w/ original surgeon that did my surgery and was told it went to the skin line and he could not take any more skin? Though I was told I had a skin sparing mastectomy? Well, the thought now, is this will be taken care of through radiation w/ a "boost" to the area in question, unless this new surgeon thinks she can get more under surgery. If no surgery, I begin chemo Thursday, and that (should) be the plan. IDK for sure. Any experience w/ what skin line means? Today is a good day to be a good day! Dx 12/3/2014, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 0/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Surgery 12/30/2014 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2014 03:01PM kris1114 wrote: Ok and thank you. Hard right now not knowing the staging. I say this because I felt thickening in 2011. My old gynecologist brushed it off completely to fibrocystic change and told me that I do not need to worry about it and will have mammos beginning at 40yrs old. At the TIME, I heard what I needed to hear and forgot about it until I discovered the lump and nipple retraction this month. I now know and urge everyone to be YOUR OWN HEALTH ADVOCATE at all times. PLEASE. Kristin

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2014 08:18PM kris1114 wrote: My results came back as cancer, but PLEASE read around the forum as most of the people who were in the same position as us waiting on biopsy reports came back as B9. There ARE benign conditions that can mimic cancer, but I know the waiting can be positively BRUTAL. You have your age on your side. Please update when you get your results. I will be thinking about you. I am 39. PM me if you need to talk ok? Kristin

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2014 03:50PM kris1114 wrote: Mixed Ductal and Lobular invasive carcinomas. Doc suspects some in situ as well. 3 cancerous tumors at 3,4, and 6 o'clock. 1cm, 2cm and 1.2cm. Estrogen and Progesterone receptors strong positive. HER-2 test pending but I was assured it would be back Monday. I am going to call when they open as the office is 35 miles from my house. I am not a candidate for a lumpectomy. I had genetic counseling this past Tuesday that will be back in 3 weeks. I will have an MRI of the left breast which was deemed clear via mammogram, but just be sure w/ MRI and genetic testing.
Posts.Title: Abnormal Mammo and US. Biopsy next. kris1114 kris1114

Posts.Content: kris1114 wrote: Hello, I am new here. I noted a breast mass and nipple retraction on November the 7th. Went for a diagnostic Mammo today. They took a bunch of pics. I was sent out to the waiting room and called back for more mammogram pictures. Then, I was taken back for an ultrasound. The technician was stopping and measuring what felt like constantly. The doctor came in and looked at the pics and ultrasounded herself. They measured and talked quitely. She gave me a towel and said that the Mammogram and ultrasound looked very worriesome. Since she had just ultrasounded the lymphnodes, I asked if they were normal and the doctor said yes. I was shaken up and said that is good right? She said yes it is. I said you are worried about cancer then. She said yes I am. She said there were 4 tumors that grew into one. I basically drew a blank and it felt surreal. I hadn't a clue what to ask. I was sent to another area to schedule a core biopsy. The nurse said it could be benign, or hyperplasia or cancer. She was reassuring, but also not in the room during diagnostics. The doctor that was in the room was solemn, quite and her eyes seem to tell me that she felt strongly it was cancer. What should I be asking? Any advice? Biopsy is Monday. December.1st. I am listening and ready to learn. Kristin Today is a good day to be a good day! Posts.Content: kris1114 wrote: Friends. I had a core biopsy Monday. Today Wednesday at 3pm, I was diagnosed with Breast cancer. They are doing tests to find out if it is Ductal or Lobular and if it is sensitive to Estrogene and Progesterone. I was told I need to see the surgeon for a consult, but to expect Chemo, radiation and a mastectomy. I will know the staging once I have surgery. BUT, my LYMPH nodes are not currently enlarged and look normal. I hope this is a good sign. The hospital said generally speaking with no lymph enlargement (not that it can't be in the lymph nodes), but that in general it will mean stage 0,1, or 2. Please, any questions and information, please send it my way. Thank you!!! Kristin Today is a good day to be a good day! Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2014 02:54PM kris1114 wrote: I developed a large Hematoma after my core biopsy this was on 12/1. It still hurts. They did not mention a size or removing it. They just said it was fairly big. But it did bleed a lot and bleed for a day off and on afterwards. They had me icing it and Tylenol, then after a week I was told to switch to heat. I had them after I had a hysterectomy as well from Heparin shots in my abdomen to prevent clots. They all went away after about 1-2 weeks.
Posts.Title: Huge hematoma ? AnnieNJS kris1114

Posts.Content: kris1114 wrote: Ok, after every surgery I have ever had, I get a sore throat from the trach tube of course, happened in 2011 after appendectomy, and last year after hysterectomy, AND spasms in lower throat. It happened again after double Mastectomy on 12/30/14, but subsided after about 3 days. Now, I had my port placement on 1/28/15 and it was done awake! No trach tube, but major throat spasms directly after that is getting worse. Worse I have ever felt. Also, mastectomy site got angry and swelled for some reason. Spasms are, lower esophagus, into chest, light shortness of breath. Hurts to bend over, cough, sneeze and talk. Called radialogy nurse on call, and they told me to come in the morning and they may send me to my oncologist. But, since this is a familiar feeling, I am going to call my surgeon, the one that did the mastectomy tomorrow morning. They said if shortness of breath gets worse, go to ER and I will if I have to. Anybody have a CLUE what I am talking about? Possible light injury to esophagal lining or something that flared up? Something like that that only time can heal? Will call in morning. For now, no real speaking and ice on throat. WEIRD!!!! Kristin Today is a good day to be a good day! Posts.Content: Feb 10, 2015 04:03AM kris1114 wrote: Hello. They cannot give you a stage until after they can remove the entire tumor and know it's complete size and stats so to speak. I was originally thought to have had 2.7cm via core biopsy guided ultrasound. After surgery, it ended up being 8.6cm. 2.7cm invasive, with the rest being in situ (contained). If you do not have a multi focal disease like me (multiple tumors in same breast) you may be a lumpectomy candidate. You sound like you are very strong!

Posts.Content: Jan 8, 2015 09:30AM kris1114 wrote: My surgeon said 3-5 days on the final pathology report. This was on Dec.30th 2014 when I had my BMX. I asked about the oncotype test and he said that would be included but did not mention it taking 2 weeks. My oncologist said I would start chemo in about 3-4 weeks after surgery and I wonder if the oncotype test is a big deciding factor in a hormone positive individual. I did score a 40 in the KI-67 antigen test the one that determines how many of the cancer cells are dividing. So 60% are not and 40% are and was told anything over 20 is unfavorable. Just wondering Kristin
Posts.Title: can i demand Oncotype Dx testing zha-an kris1114

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2015 03:31AM kris1114 wrote: DVT. (Deep vein thrombosis) but! PE (Pumonary embolism) ruled out! Caught it early through my persistence! Be your own health advocate. Flushed port with Heparin and I will be on Xarelta (blood thinner) for a long time due to high risk for reoccurence. Thanks for pushing me to take action! Could have been bad if ignored. Thanks again! Kristin

Posts.Content: Dec 15, 2014 09:02AM kris1114 wrote: When I had my biopsy, they did not warn me of potential Lidocaine side effects. It may not happen to you, but it did to me, but nothing at all over the top, but worth mentioning. Shaking and jitteryness. Racey heart, and heavy compression feeling in chest. Much like an asthma attack and using a Proventil inhaler afterwards. Also, sedation! Again nothing I couldn't handle, but I DO wish they had warned me. I do not like being blindsided. Good luck, Kristin
